bibl.title: Letter to Henry Rose Carter, May 29, 1922

div1.p: The writer, from the treasury department of the U.S. Public Health Service, expresses a desire to discuss with Carter a plan to put European ports under the general direction of U.S. Quarantine Station, on Staten Island, New York.

div1.head: Letter to Henry Rose Carter, May 29, 1922
div1.opener:
SBG:EI
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
U. S. QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
ROSEBANK
STATEN ISLAND, N.Y.
May 29, 1922.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I received your reprint “Yellow Fever in Peru” several days ago
but did not acknowledge the receipt of it as I wanted to have time
first to read it over carefully from beginning to end, and this I have
only been able to do recently.

The article is of especial interest to me after my experience on
the West coast and especially in Peru, and I am sure it is a real con-
tribution to our knowledge of yellow fever and brings out so well that
stegomyia control is the fundamental thing, a fact which I find many
people with yellow fever experience do not know or are not willing to
concede.

I especially enjoyed your classification of society in Payta
based on the number of water containers each possessed.

I have heard from Hansen several times, once a few weeks ago. He
says he is willing to leave Latin America forever, but I doubt if he
will be satisfied away from such a troubled existence after the experiences
he has been through.

I hope sometime soon to be able to talk over with you a plan that I
have regarding the Quarantine work of this station. As a plan it is yet
rather hazy, but the principles are clear and are those that I advocated
and finally started at Panama, and in which you always supported me. The
basis is that the European Ports should act under the general direction
of this Station and that our measures should be light or severe depending
upon the manner in which precautions at European ports were taken. At the
same time this station could be the center where the best methods to be
taken at European Ports could be determined in order that the best methods
could be actually determined and their use be standardized.

At present the measures put into effect at European ports and upon the
voyage, while very much improved, are not standard, and are open to con-
siderable improvement. I find it difficult to keep informed as to conditions
and what is actually being done.
